info.title: Opentrons OT-2 HTTP API Spec
info.description: This OpenAPI spec describes the HTTP API of the Opentrons OT-2. It may be retrieved from a robot on port 31950 at /openapi. Some schemas used in requests and responses use the `x-patternProperties` key to mean the JSON Schema `patternProperties` behavior.

logPaths.description: List of URL paths at which to find logs

ipAddress.description: The interface IP address with CIDR subnet appended (e.g. 10.0.0.1/24)

macAddress.description: The MAC address of this interface (at least when connected to this network - it may change due to NetworkManager's privacy functionality when disconnected or connected to a different network)

gatewayAddress.description: The address of the configured gateway

type.description: What kind of interface this is

interfaces.description: Per-interface networking status. Properties are named for network interfaces

v1ErrorMessage.description: An error response with a human readable message

v1ErrorWithTraceback.description: An error response with a human readable message and a dumped traceback

traceback.description: A traceback dump from the server, in multiline text

uri.description: A URI for the key (mostly for use with DELETE /wifi/keys/{key_id})

id.description: A contents hash of the key used to specify the key in POST /wifi/configure (and also to determine the key URI)

name.description: The original filename of the key

currentTemp.description: The current temperature of the module

targetTemp.description: The target temperature of the module if any

engaged.description: Whether the magnets are raised or lowered

height.description: The height of the top of the magnets relative to their home position, in mm

lid.description: The current state of the lid

lidTarget.description: The target temperature of the lid temperature controller

lidTemp.description: The current temperature of the lid

currentTemp.description: The current temperature of the thermocycler block

targetTemp.description: The target temperature of the thermocycler block

holdTime.description: The time left in the current hold step, if any (in seconds)

rampRate.description: The current ramp rate (in degC/s) for the thermocycler block

currentCycleIndex.description: The index of the current cycle within the current programmed sequence

totalCycleCount.description: The total number of cycles within the current sequence

currentStepIndex.description: The index of the current step within the current programmed cycle

totalStepCount.description: The total number of steps within the current cycle

attachedPipette.description: Pipette (if any) attached to the mount

model.description: The model of the attached pipette. These are snake case as in the Protocol API. This includes the full version string

name.description: The name of the attached pipette - the model without the version string

tip_length.description: The default tip length for this pipette, if attached

mount_axis.description: The axis that moves this pipette up and down

plunger_axis.description: The axis that moves this pipette's plunger

id.description: The serial number of the attached pipette

motionTarget.description: What should be moved. If mount, move the nominal position of the mount; if pipette, move the nozzle of the pipette

point.description: A point in deck coordinates (x, y, z)

lightState.description: Whether a light is (or should be turned) on or off

mount.description: A valid pipette mount location to specify for motion or interrogation

deckCalibrationPoint.description: The name of a point relative to deck calibration. The number points are calibration crosses ("1" in slot 1, "2" in slot 3, "3" in slot 7); "safeZ" is a safe height above the deck, "attachTip" is a good place to go for the user to attach a tip.

tipLength.description: The length of the tip you are prompting the user to attach

advancedSettings.description: A list of advanced settings and their values

old_id.description: The ID by which the property used to be known; not useful now and may contain spaces or hyphens

title.description: A human-readable short string suitable for display as the title of the setting

description.description: A human-readable long string suitable for display as a paragraph or two explaining the setting

restart_required.description: Whether a robot restart is required to make this change take effect

value.description: Whether the setting is off by previous user choice (false), true by user choice (true), or off and has never been altered (null)

v2ErrorMessage.description: An error message with a shortname, a longer name, and some other props

error.description: A machine-readable shortname for the error that has occurred

message.description: A human-readable message for display about the error

*.description: A URI that can be requested to execute the operation named by the property

fields.description: The fields of the pipette settings

*.description: A pipette config element identified by the property's name

units.description: The physical units this value is in (e.g. mm, uL)

min.description: The minimum acceptable value of the property

max.description: The maximum acceptable value of the property

default.description: The default value of the property

value.description: The current value of the property

quirks.summary: Pipette config elements that are binary in nature
quirks.description: Quirks are behavioral changes associated with pipettes. For instance, some models of pipette might need to run their drop tip behavior twice. Specific pipettes have specific valid quirks which can then be enabled or disabled; quirks that are not originally defined as compatible with a specific kind of pipette cannot be added to an incompatible pipette. Because quirks are only defined as compatible for a pipette if they should be on, the default value for all quirks is true.

*.description: Whether the quirk is enabled or not

serverDown.description: Error from the reverse proxy indicating the API server is not up

advancedSettings.description: A dump of advanced settings and suitable links for next action

restart.description: A URI to POST to restart the robot. If this is present, it must be requested for any settings changes to take effect

tags.name: networking
tags.description: Controls or queries the OT-2's network connectivity

tags.name: control
tags.description: Operations that affect the OT-2's hardware

tags.name: modules
tags.description: Operations having to do with connected modules

tags.name: pipettes
tags.description: Operations having to do with pipettes

tags.name: settings
tags.description: Operations for viewing or editing robot configuration

tags.name: metadata
tags.description: Operations involving robot or server metadata

externalDocs.description: More documentation for the OT-2 is here

404.description: The spec requested is not found

get.description: Retrieve some useful information about supported API versions, names, and so on
get.summary: The /health endpoint is a good one to check to see if you're communicating with an OT-2 with a properly booted API server. If it returns OK, all is well. It also can be used to pull information like the robot software version and name.

200.description: A set of information about the name and versions.

name.description: The robot's name. In most cases the same as its mDNS advertisement domain name but this can get out of sync. Mostly useful for user-facing titles.

api_version.description: The SemVer dotted-int version of the API server and by extension robot software.

fw_version.description: The version of the firmware flashed to the OT-2's motor controller board. Doesn't follow a pattern, suitable only for display or exact matching.

system_version.description: The SemVer dotted-int version of the robot OS

apiLog.description: The URI of the api logs

serialLog.description: The URI of the serial logs

apiSpec.description: The URI to this API specification

get.description: Query the current network connectivity state
get.summary: Gets information about the OT-2's network interfaces including their connectivity, their addresses, and their networking info

500.description: An internal error occurred, probably from NetworkManager. Same schema as the 200, but empty

get.summary: Scans for beaconing WiFi networks and returns the list of visible ones along with some data about their security and strength

signal.description: A unitless signal strength; a higher number is a better signal

active.description: Whether there is a connection active

security.description: The raw NetworkManager output about the wifi security

post.summary: Configures the wireless network interface to connect to a network

requestBody.description: Configuration options for the wireless network interface

ssid.description: The SSID to connect to. If this isn't an SSID that is being broadcast by a network, you should also set hidden to true.

hidden.description: True if the network is hidden (not broadcasting an ssid). False (default if key is not present) otherwise

psk.description: If this is a PSK-secured network (securityType is wpa-psk), the PSK

eapConfig.description: All options required to configure EAP access to the wifi. All options should match one of the cases described in /wifi/eap-options; for instance, configuring for peap/mschapv2 should have "peap/mschapv2" as the eapType; it should have "identity" and "password" props, both of which are identified as mandatory in /wifi/eap-options; and it may also have "anonymousIdentity" and "caCert" properties, both of which are identified as present but not required.

eapType.description: Which (supported) EAP variant to configure for. Must be one of the types returned by /wifi/eap-options.

pskNetwork.summary: Connect to a WPA2-PSK secured network
pskNetwork.description: This is the "standard" way to set up a WiFi router, and is where you provide a password

hiddenNetwork.summary: Connect to a network not broadcasting its SSID, with a PSK

eapNetwork.summary: Connect to a network secured by WPA2-EAP using PEAP/MSCHAPv2
eapNetwork.description: WPA2 Enterprise network security is based around the EAP protocol, which is a very complex tunneled authentication protocol. It can be configured in many different ways. The OT-2 supports several but by no means all of these variants. The variants supported on a given OT-2 can be found by GET /wifi/eap-options. This example describes how to set up PEAP/MSCHAPv2, which is an older EAP variant that was at one time the mechanism securing Eduroam.

201.description: The OT-2 successfully connected to the specified network using the specified parameters

400.description: A malformed response body of some kind

example.message: Error: JSONDecodeError in /wifi/configure: Expecting delimiter at position 0

401.description: The response body was properly formed but the OT-2 could not connect to the specified network, likely because some configuration or password does not match

example.message: Secrets were required but not provided

/wifi/keys.description: Keyfile management for the various kinds of Wifi authentication that require private key data

get.description: Get a list of key files known to the system

keys.description: A list of keys in the system

post.description: Send a new key file to the OT-2

201.description: The details of the newly uploaded key

200.description: The details of the file, which was already present

parameters.name: key_uuid
parameters.description: The ID of key to delete, as determined by a previous call to GET /wifi/keys

delete.description: Delete a key file from the OT-2

get.description: Get the supported EAP variants and their configuration parameters

200.description: An object describing all supported EAP variants and their parameters

items.description: An object describing an EAP variant

name.description: The identifier for the EAP variant

displayName.description: A human-readable formatted name for the EAP variant

options.description: A list of objects describing configuration options for the EAP variant

items.description: An object describing the name and format of an EAP config option

name.description: The name of the config option

displayName.description: A human-readable and nicely formatted name for the option

required.description: Whether the option is required for this EAP variant or optional

type.description: The type of the value. If string, a non-sensitive string like a username. If password, a sensitive string like a passphrase for a keyfile or a password. If file, upload the file with POST /wifi/keys and pass the hash.

post.description: Blink the OT-2's gantry lights so you can pick it out of a crowd

parameters.name: seconds
parameters.description: Time to blink the lights for

200.description: A notification that the identification procedure has begun

get.description: Describe the modules attached to the OT-2

200.description: A list of all attached modules and the status of each one

name.description: A machine readable identifying name for a module

displayName.description: A human-presentable name of the module

port.description: The virtual port to which the module is attached

serial.description: The unique serial number of the module

model.description: The model identifier (i.e. the part number)

get.description: Get live data for a specific module
get.summary: This is similar to the values in GET /modules, but for only a specific currently-attached module

post.description: Execute a command on a specific module
post.summary: Command a module to take an action. Valid actions depend on the specific module attached, which is the model value from GET /modules/{serial}/data or GET /modules

command_type.description: The name of the module function to call

args.description: The ordered args list for the call

tempModSetTemp.description: Set the temperature of an attached Temperature Module

200.description: The result of a successful call

returnValue.description: The return value from the call

tempModSetTemperature.description: A successful call to set_temperature on a Temperature Module

value.message: Module does not have command: sort_timecards

post.description: Capture an image from the OT-2's onboard camera and return it

500.description: Something went wrong when taking the picture

parameters.name: refresh
parameters.description: If true, actively scan for attached pipettes. Note: this requires disabling the pipette motors and should only be done when no protocol is running and you know it won't cause a problem

get.summary: This endpoint lists properties of the pipettes currently attached to the robot like name, model, and mount. It queries a cached value unless the refresh query parameter is set to true, in which case it will actively scan for pipettes. This requires disabling the pipette motors (which is done automatically) and therefore should only be done through user intent

get.description: Query which motors are engaged and holding

post.description: Disengage a motor or set of motors

requestBody.description: A list of motor axes to disengage

400.description: Bad request body or nonexistent axes

get.description: Get a list of useful positions

move.description: Move robot to a position identified by the response

post.description: Move the robot's gantry to a position (usually to a position retrieved from GET /robot/positions)

requestBody.description: Specify the place to move to (as a point) and the thing to move (combining motion target, mount, and model if necessary)

model.description: A pipette model that matches the pipette attached to the specified mount. Required if target is "pipette"

moveLeftMount.description: Move the left mount, regardless of what is attached to that mount, to a specific position. Since you move the mount, the end of the pipette will be in different places depending on what pipette is attached - but you don't have to know what's attached.

moveRightP300Single.summary: Move P300 Single on right mount
moveRightP300Single.description: Move a P300 Single attached to the right mount to a specific position. You have to specify that it's a P300 Single that you're moving, but as long as you specify the correct model the end of the pipette will always be at the specified position.

example.message: Invalid target key: 'robot' (target must be one of 'mount' or 'pipette')

target.description: What to home. Robot means to home all axes; pipette, only that pipette's carriage and pipette axes

mount.description: Which mount to home, if target is "pipette" (required in that case)

example.message: Expected 'left' or 'right' as values for mountgot top instead.

get.description: Get the current status of the OT-2's rail lights

200.description: The status of the rail lights

post.description: Turn the rail lights on or off

200.description: The new state of the lights

post.description: Begin (or restart) a deck calibration session

requestBody.description: Send a json formatted body as described here to force refresh the deck calibration session if one is ongoing

force.description: Set to true to refresh the session

dispatch.description: Dispatch deck calibration commands once you have a session

token.description: The token to send along in future deck calibration actions

pipette.description: Details of the pipette the system has selected for use in deck calibration

model.description: The model of the pipette attached in this mount

403.description: No pipette is attached, or the attached pipette cannot be read

409.description: There is already a session in progress

forceBegin.description: Re-request a session and force refresh

example.message: Error, session in progress. Use  "force" key in request body to override

requestBody.description: The operation to execute and any required parameters

savexy.description: Save the XY position of cross 2 (in slot 3)

attachTip.description: Inform the OT-2 that a tip is attached

detachTip.description: Inform the OT-2 that a tip has been removed

saveZ.description: Save the current Z position as the height of the deck

saveTransform.description: Save the current transform after saving all positions

example.message: Session must be started before issuing commands

400.description: Internal assertion failure, probably from a bad request

example.message: Exception FileNotFoundError raised by dispatch of move: <traceback>

requestBody.description: Configure the setting to change and the new value

id.description: The ID of the setting to change (something returned by GET /settings)

value.description: The new value to set. If null, reset to default

calibrateToBottom.description: Tell the robot to move to the bottom of labware wells during labware calibration

resetHomeOnBoot.description: Regardless of current setting, reset the Disable Home On Boot setting to its default

get.description: Get a list of available advanced settings (feature flags) and their values

post.description: Set the minimum level of logs saved locally

log_level.description: The value to set (conforming to Python log levels)

post.description: Set the minimum level of logs sent upstream to Opentrons. Only available on a real robot

log_level.description: The value to set (conforming to Python log levels)

get.description: Get the settings that can be reset as part of factory reset

200.description: Available things to reset as factory reset

id.description: A short machine-readable id for the setting

name.description: A short human-readable name for the setting

description.description: A longer human-readable description of the setting

post.description: Perform a factory reset of some robot data

requestBody.description: The specific elements of robot data to reset

schema.description: An object whose property names describe the resets to perform. Property names must be taken from the ids of the response of /settings/reset/options

*.description: True to request a reset of this option; null (or not present) otherwise

200.description: The robot settings, which are currently not schema controlled and may change without warning

get.description: List all settings for all known pipettes by id

200.description: Settings for each pipette, keyed by the pipette ID

get.description: Get the settings of a specific pipette by ID

post.description: Change the settings of a specific pipette

*.description: A setting, with its key as the name of the setting (the same as in the GET). Quirks should be inlined in the same format, next to other settings

oneOf.description: The format if this is a quirk. Null means reset
The format if this is not a quirk. Must be between max and min for this property. Null means reset

200.description: Setting changed OK. Dumps the new settings for the pipette

412.description: A specified value was out of range
